entry.title: Demystifying the OAuth2 SAML Bearer Assertion usage in SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
1. Introduction:

In the rapidly evolving landscape of enterprise integration, authentication and authorization are no longer mere checkpoints ‚Äî they are the guardians of trust between systems. Within SAP Integration Suite, the OAuth 2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion & JWT Bearer grant types stand out as a powerful yet often less-understood mechanisms for secure API access, especially in hybrid enterprise landscapes where user identity is federated across multiple systems.

If you have ever stared at an urn:ietf:params:oauth:grant-type:saml2-bearer or urn:ietf:params:oauth:grant-type:jwt-bearer parameter as a supported grant type and wondered how this elegant string actually translates into a trusted access token, you are not alone. Many integration developers and security practitioners have encountered it ‚Äî often through trial, error, and a bit of documentation spelunking.

In this article, we‚Äôll go beyond the surface. We‚Äôll explore:

  • What OAuth2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion is really doing under the hood ‚Äî and why it exists in the first place.
  • How this plays into SAP Integration Suite‚Äôs XSUAA and the broader BTP security model, particularly in securing IFlows and APIs within SAP Integration Suite.
  • Practical configuration patterns and gotchas that can save you hours of troubleshooting.
  • A few examples of exchanging a signed SAML assertion for an OAuth access token, demystifying the process step by step.

2. When is the OAuth2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion relevant for an Integration Developer?

Traditionally, most communication handled by Cloud Integration has been system-to-system, where a technical client or application authenticates itself, and the user context is irrelevant. In such scenarios, the Client Credentials grant type has been sufficient, since all that mattered was verifying that the calling system was trusted.

But this picture is evolving. Today, IFlows and APIs are two sides of the same coin: while IFlows orchestrate integration logic, APIs expose functionality that must often act on behalf of a specific user. Increasingly, organizations expect end-user identity and authorizations established in one system (e.g., via a corporate IdP or another SAP application) to be seamlessly propagated into Cloud Integration and carried forward all the way to the backend system.

This is exactly where the OAuth 2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion grant type becomes relevant. It provides a standards-based mechanism to exchange a trusted user identity assertion for an access token in Cloud Integration. That access token can then be forwarded downstream, ensuring that the original user‚Äôs context ‚Äî along with their authorizations ‚Äî is preserved across system boundaries.

For the integration developer, this means that Cloud Integration is no longer just a technical middleware layer. It becomes an active participant in identity propagation, enabling end-to-end security models that align with enterprise zero-trust principles and modern API-driven architectures.

üìåTo demonstrate the concepts required for achieving identity propagation, this article utilizes the SAP Cloud Connector, X.509 certificates, and backend configurations that I have already explained in detail in my earlier blog post on technical user propagation. While that post specifically focuses on technical user propagation, the configuration steps are not very different for the user propagation scenario described here. I therefore recommend that readers familiarize themselves with those concepts first, as they provide a solid foundation for this discussion.

üìåOne of the scenarios in this blog post will also refer back to the earlier article to highlight the applicability of the authorization code grant type in Cloud Integration‚Äîparticularly when authorizing users from a corporate IdP such as Entra ID, using OpenID Connect‚Äìbased federation in conjunction with SAP Cloud Identity Services (SAP IAS). For a broader perspective, I also suggest referring to my linked blog post, which explains single sign-on to SAP Cloud Integration runtime from an external application.

Taken together, these resources provide a complete 360-degree view of securing and implementing user-linked flows in SAP Integration Suite.

3. Full support for OAuth2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion in Cloud Integration

It is important to emphasize that SAP Cloud Integration fully supports the OAuth2 SAML Bearer Assertion flow both at the 'sender' and at the 'receiver' side.

  1. On the inbound side, Cloud Integration can authenticate and authorize incoming requests based on the user‚Äôs identity, ensuring that calls made to IFlows are evaluated not just at the technical client level but also with the context of the end user. This enables developers to enforce fine-grained authorization rules and maintain auditability of user actions. 
    The following simplified illustration shows how OAuth2 SAML and JWT Bearer grants act as the enablers that make this flow possible.

    You can specify these grant types while creating a service instance for the Process Integration Runtime.
    Here's an example snippet to create a service instance with the SAMLBearer and JWTBearer grant types        
  2. On the outbound side, Cloud Integration can establish an OAuth2 SAML Bearer Assertion when calling downstream systems such as SAP SuccessFactors, SAP S/4HANA Cloud,  S/4HANA On-Premise (wrapped under the familiar Principal Propagation pattern), etc.
    1. Note: This capability is not new. Even in the days of Neo, Cloud Integration has supported the OAuth2 SAML Bearer flow for connecting to SAP SuccessFactors ‚Äî both through technical credentials and via user-based assertions using an email identifier. The topic has been well covered in the community, including several blog posts authored by my colleague, Deepak Deshpande. (here and here)
    2. Beyond this, any system within the BTP ecosystem that leverages the BTP Connectivity Service‚Äîincluding S/4HANA Cloud‚Äîcan take part in the identity propagation chain. In the sections that follow, we will explore some of the possibilities this enables, such as chaining into another iFlow (within the same or a different subaccount) or invoking a service exposed through OData Provisioning.

This dual capability positions Cloud Integration as a true enabler of end-to-end user identity propagation, bridging the gap between modern identity-aware APIs and enterprise backend systems, while ensuring security models remain consistent across landscapes.

4. Understanding the "SAML" in OAuth2 SAML Bearer Assertion

The term OAuth2 SAML Bearer Assertion (RFC: RFC 7522) can often feel confusing at first glance, particularly with the placement of the word 'SAML'.

"Where is SAML in this picture?", you may ask,  as practitioners know for a fact that SAP BTP is based on OAuth2.0 and OIDC-based security standards. Let's unpack this.

Fundamentally, classical Identity Providers (IdP) like Entra ID, SAP IAS, or corporate ADFS are designed to issue signed assertions asserting a user‚Äôs identity and attributes. These assertions are trusted pieces of information that downstream systems can use to authenticate a user without requiring them to re-enter credentials.  In addition, in an enterprise integration landscape, the Identity Provider role is not limited to classical IdPs. Connectivity and middleware components themselves can also act as an Identity Provider and trusted issuers of SAML assertions. The process of SAML to OAuth2 token exchange sequence is as follows :

  1. The SAML assertion issued by the assumed Identity Provider acts as a 'credential wrapper' ‚Äî it carries the authenticated user identity, roles, and authorizations.
  2. The Authorization Server (in BTP Integration Suite tenant,  i.e., XSUAA) consumes this signed assertion and, if trusted and valid, exchanges it for an OAuth 2.0 access token, per the RFC spec (RFC 7522).
  3. This access token, representing the user identity, can then be presented to the target system, which, based on its security directive, can authenticate and authorize the identity from the token.

Let's look at a few notable examples where this process is at play:

  1. The classical approach to setting up a SAML trust between an Identity Provider and a Service Provider lends itself to setting up for the OAuth2 bearer exchange flow, particularly between Entra ID and SAP BTP, based on the 'on-behalf-of' directive. Explained so elegantly in these two blog posts authored by Martin and Niklas, respectively, applicable for services secured by the BTP XSUAA Service.
    Note that this classical 'trust' setup also equally applies between, say, Entra ID and SAP NetWeaver ABAP AS. Martin Pankraz and I demonstrated the setup in this blog post.
  2. SAP BTP Connectivity Service can generate signed SAML assertions when bridging secure connections to backend systems. For example, the BTP Destination type 'OAuth2SAMLBearerAssertion' leverages this principal. See example below:
     
  3. API Management's gateway acts as an identity provider that injects a user‚Äôs authenticated identity into a signed assertion to downstream services. Customers frequently use policy templates like this one listed in the API Business Accelerator Hub.
  4. Cloud Integration itself uses the BTP Connectivity Services' principles by providing out-of-the-box Security Materials that support OAuth2 SAML Bearer exchange. We'll get to more of this bit in this very blog post. 

This means that within the BTP ecosystem, the ability to mint a signed SAML assertion is not confined to a single component but distributed across the connectivity and security services that are orchestrating secure communication flows.

Put simply, the "SAML" in OAuth2 SAML Bearer Assertion is the trusted identity assertion format that enables one system to confidently vouch for a user‚Äôs identity to another. When combined with OAuth 2.0, it bridges the gap between user-centric authentication (SAML) and token-based authorization (OAuth).

On that note, you may have come across the OAuth2 JWT Bearer grant type as well. Let‚Äôs weave that into our context.

5. The OAuth2 JWT Bearer grant type

While the OAuth2 SAML Bearer grant type leverages a SAML 2.0 assertion to obtain an access token, its close cousin ‚Äî the OAuth2 JWT Bearer grant type ‚Äî follows a similar token exchange pattern but uses a signed JSON Web Token (JWT) instead of SAML. In the context of SAP BTP XSUAA, the JWT Bearer flow is often chosen when the identity assertion is already in JWT format, such as when integrating with systems that natively issue JWTs (e.g., other BTP applications, certain identity providers, or trusted microservices).

However, for the purposes of this article, we will not be focusing on the JWT Bearer approach. The reason is that SAP Cloud Integration only partially supports it ‚Äî JWT Bearer can be used when authenticating inbound requests to an iFlow, but it is not available as a selectable option in the ‚ÄúSecurity Material‚Äù when making outbound calls from Cloud Integration to a target system. As such, its utility is currently more limited in end-to-end integration scenarios compared to the SAML Bearer flow.

6. Configurations needed to achieve OAuth2 SAML Bearer exchange

Since we are on the topic of the role of Identity Providers (actual or assumed) during an OAuth2 SAML Bearer handshake, let us weave in the role of the Trust Configuration setting in the BTP Cockpit ‚Äî a subject that is often less understood in the context of SAP Integration Suite.

Why is this less understood?


In BTP landscapes, the Trust Configuration in the cockpit is primarily associated with browser-based BTP applications that require coupling between an Identity Provider (IdP) (such as SAP IAS or a corporate IdP) and the Service Provider (SP) role of the application. This trust relationship governs how users log in interactively to applications and how their identities are federated.

This implies that at the design time (UI) level, configuring the Trust relationship ensures that developers and administrators can access the Integration Suite tools via their corporate IDP.

However, customers often struggle to apply the same concept when it comes to the runtime ‚Äî where iFlows and APIs need to be authenticated and authorized via user identities. This is precisely where dialing in the correct runtime configurations for OAuth2 SAML Bearer exchange becomes critical.

To keep this practical, let‚Äôs break the discussion into multiple scenarios and examine the configurations required for each. Here is a table that captures the different scenarios covered in this blog post :

Scenario 1 [INBOUND] Invoking an IFlow via BTP Destination / Connectivity Service
Scenario 2 variant 1

Scenario 1 + [OUTBOUND] Using Security Material to make an outbound OAuth2 SAML Bearer call

Scenario 2 variant 2 Authorization Code grant type  + [OUTBOUND] Using Security Material to make an outbound OAuth2 SAML Bearer call

6.1. Scenario 1: [INBOUND] Invoking an IFlow via a BTP Destination:

There are use cases where a Fiori/UI5 application deployed on BTP uses a destination to call an IFlow, ensuring the user‚Äôs identity (via OAuth2 SAML Bearer) is securely propagated into the integration layer. Similarly, SAP Build Process Automation can leverage destinations in its Actions framework to trigger IFlows as part of an automated workflow, often requiring identity propagation so that downstream systems know which user initiated the process. Beyond these, other scenarios include SAP Work Zone or SAP Launchpad extensions invoking integration services, as well as custom applications running in the Cloud Foundry runtime consuming iFlows via destinations.

In practice, customers often face challenges in identifying the correct configurations to make this scenario work. Below is a detailed cluster of the configurations involved.

  1. OAuth token endpoint address: Customers often assume the default '.../oauth/token' endpoint applies universally, but this is not the case. OAuthSAMLBearer looks for the '.../oauth/token/alias/' endpoint. 
  2. Exchange of trust between subaccounts where the services reside.
  3. Implicit trust within the same subaccount: Even if both services are in the same subaccount, an implicit trust relationship must still be established. This small step can save hours of troubleshooting.
  4. BTP Destination and Integration Flow settings to support OAuth2 SAML Bearer handshake.
  5. A quick walkthrough of the SAP Business Application Studio template wizard building blocks, enabling an SAP Fiori application to validate everything completed so far.

Here is a solution blueprint of what we will put together:

Let‚Äôs review these configurations step by step.

1. OAuth token alias endpoint.

Step No

Description

Screenshot

1.Download the 'SAML Metadata' from the 'Trust Configuration' section of your BTP Cockpit
2.Locate and copy the value of the 'entityID' element from the downloaded XML file
3.

Locate and copy the 'Location' element. There are multiple attributes present; make sure you copy the one that contains the '.../oauth/token/alias/...' URL pattern.

This will be the token endpoint we will use in subsequent configuration screens.

 

2. & 3. Exchange of Trust between subaccount / Implicit trust within the same subaccount.

Follow the instructions in this BTP help guide: construct the EntityDescriptor metadata exactly as specified and upload it as Trusted Metadata in your target subaccount‚Äînamely, the subaccount hosting the Integration Suite.

Step No.

Identify your source and target subaccounts, and carefully construct the EntityDescriptor snippet using the settings provided in the User Propagation between Cloud Foundry Applications guide.

üí°Note: As mentioned earlier, this step is required even if the source and target services reside within the same BTP subaccount. In such cases, the configuration establishes a self-trust relationship.

2.Go to the Destination Trust section in your BTP Cockpit of the source subaccount and import the Active Trust Certificate. In addition, follow the recommended best practices to set up a Passive Trust Certificate as well, ensuring a smooth switchover and preventing disruptions when the active certificate approaches expiry.

üí°Disable the Available for User Logon and Create Shadow User options. Disabling the latter ensures that only pre-onboarded users are propagated, which is more secure than allowing all users to be automatically created and propagated.

5.Because we disabled shadow user creation, go to the Users section and explicitly create the users that need to be propagated. 
6.Once the user has been created, we still need to ensure that the necessary roles and scopes from the source token are available for propagation. There are two ways to achieve this. The simplest approach is to assign the newly created user to a Role Collection that includes the MessagingSend role.
7. Rather than explicitly assigning individual users to a role collection, a more elegant approach is to map a group from the identity provider to the desired role collection. This ensures that the corresponding scopes from the original token are automatically granted to the user principal in the target token as well.

4. BTP Destination and IFlow settings:

2.

3. 

To demonstrate an end-to-end flow, I‚Äôve created an IFlow that uses an OData V2 adapter at both the Sender and Receiver. This approach was chosen because SAP Business Application Studio makes it straightforward to build a Fiori app that consumes an OData service.

This first variant of the receiver adapter connects to an S/4HANA On-premise backend using principal propagation. It demonstrates how an inbound OAuth2 SAML Bearer assertion grant type carries the full user context, which can then be propagated downstream.

4.The second receiver adapter variant connects to an S/4HANA Cloud system using OAuth2 SAML Bearer security material. While we will cover this approach in the next scenario, the detailed configuration within the S/4HANA backend lies outside the scope of this blog post.
5.To test the settings, let‚Äôs shift focus to SAP Business Application Studio (BAS) in the source subaccount, where we‚Äôll build a small app that connects through the BTP Destination to the IFlow running in the target subaccount, using the OAuth2 SAML Bearer bridge. Note that we are using the BAS only as a means to simulate the user login experience.
6.If you encounter an error code 500 and notice no entries showing that the IFlow was invoked (for example, in the HTTP Access Log), it most likely indicates that the token exchange failed. In this case, review the configuration steps carefully to ensure accuracy.

6.2. Scenario 2:  [OUTBOUND] Using Security Material to make an outbound OAuth2 SAML Bearer call

As described in section 3.b.2, we will now focus on leveraging Cloud Integration‚Äôs capability to use the generic OAuth2 SAML Bearer security material, rather than the ones targeting SuccessFactors, as they are already well covered in the community.

One might ask: how do we set up an environment that makes it simple to simulate and test the user flow? The good news is that Scenario 1 has already given us the user interaction layer. All we need to do now is chain the IFlow we created earlier with another one, letting the outbound of the first serve as the inbound of the second. This allows us to validate the flow end-to-end in both directions.

To keep the discourse engaging, we will explore yet another variant for testing the outbound OAuth2 SAML Bearer setup. Here, we‚Äôll use Cloud Integration‚Äôs capability to trigger an Authorization Code grant type exchange, simulating a real user login, and then build on that to invoke the OAuth2 SAML Bearer method.

6.2.1. Scenario 2 - Variant 1:
Here's the solution blueprint of the first variant, where we extend scenario 1 and chain an intermediate IFlow with the main IFlow.

The sequence of events from the client to Business Application Studio follows the same pattern as in Scenario 1. The difference here is that instead of directly calling the main IFlow,  we have intentionally introduced an intermediate IFlow (step callout 1 in the blueprint above), which is configured with OAuth2 SAML Bearer security material to eventually connect with the main IFlow. Since the main IFlow accepts only the OAuth2 SAML grant type (step callout 2), this setup allows the connection to be seamlessly extended to the backend using Principal Propagation.

Regardless of whether the intermediate and main IFlows are in the same or separate subaccounts, a SAML trust between the source and target is mandatory, as highlighted in Procedure 2 of Scenario 1.

Let's take a look at the key configuration steps:

Step No.

Description

Screenshot

1.Notice that  I've created a metadata called 'self-trust' with the entityDescriptor for the subaccount. In my case, both the intermediate and main IFlow are on the same Integration Suite tenant, hence the 'self' trust.
2.Create a security material of type OAuth2 SAML Bearer. Set the target system type as 'SAP BTP (CF)'.  For the attributes, use the same settings as the ones we used in step 6.1.4.2 of the previous scenario. 
3.üí°You may notice that under the hood, this internally generates a BTP Destination in the subaccount with OAuth2SAMLBearer.
4.Notice the change here on the IFlow we built in scenario 1 (step 3 of 6.1.4). Instead of directly calling the backend URL, we have turned this into an Intermediate IFlow that chains into the final main IFlow, with the authentication set to the OAuth2 SAML Bearer security material created in step 2.
4.As you can verify in the screenshot, the main IFlow is the one that invokes the backend with principal propagation.
5.Let's go back to the app we built in scenario 1 and refresh the page. We should see the UI populate with the expected recordset after successfully negotiating the flows across the chained intermediate and main IFlows all the way to the backend.
6. As a confirmation step, look up the activity in the message processing logs (MPL) section, and you will see that both the intermediate and final IFlows were executed and in the right sequence. 

 

6.2.2. Scenario 2 - Variant 2: 
Rather than using Business Application Studio as the user-centric app to trigger the intermediate IFlow, we will instead leverage the Authorization Code grant type. From a technical perspective, the Authorization Code flow differs from the OAuth2 SAML Bearer grant; however, in principle, both achieve the same outcome: propagating a user session within an OAuth access token.

This raises the question‚Äîhow do we introduce the Authorization Code grant flow?

Cloud Integration natively supports the Authorization Code grant type as security material. While it was originally introduced to support adapters such as Dropbox and Microsoft 365, which rely on this flow, we can extend its utility further. By attaching this security material to any outbound call through the HTTP Receiver adapter‚Äîand applying a small amount of scripting (see step 6.2.2.3)‚Äîwe can retrieve an access token from the authorization code using the SecureStoreService API.

Here is a solution blueprint of what we aim to achieve:
For simplicity, a timer-based IFlow will initiate an outbound call to the intermediate IFlow, attaching an access token extracted from the security material (constructed via the authorization code exchange)  that represents an authenticated user. This user may either be provisioned through the default Cloud Identity Service or authenticated via a corporate IdP such as Entra ID, as outlined in one of my earlier blog posts. The interaction sequence between the intermediate IFlow and the final IFlow remains unchanged.

6.2.2.1 First, let's go over the configuration steps to establish the authorization code:

Step No.

Description

Screenshot

1.In your source subaccount, create a new OAuth2 Authorization Code security material. During setup, a Redirect URL will be generated‚Äîmake sure to note this URL, as it will be required in the next step when configuring a service key with the Authorization Code grant type.
2.In the BTP Cockpit, when creating a new instance of the Process Integration Runtime service, select both the Refresh Token and Authorization Code grant types. Then, paste the Redirect URL captured in Step 1 into the Redirect URI field.
3.After creating the service key, make sure to note the client credentials, along with the authorization and token URL endpoints, as these will be required in a later step.
4.

Go back to the security material creation screen and enter the parameters copied from the previous step.

You may specify a user name for the user entity you want to create, but this value will be overridden by the actual user identity provided during browser logon step.

5.After the security material is created, click on the 'Authorize' button under the ... column. This will kick off the authorization code flow process in a new browser window. and will present the auth code to the specified redirect_uri. 
6.You will be asked to authenticate yourself to an identity provider of your choosing, depending on the IDP settings as enabled in BTP's 'Trust Configuration'. Note that I'll be authenticating into SAP Identity Service, which in turn is configured to federate with multiple corporate IDPs via OIDC settings, as explained in my linked blog.
7.I'm being led into authenticating against Entra ID and my *.outlook.com email is being propagated as the authenticated user context into Cloud Integration.
8.

After successfully logging the user in, the browser redirects to the specified 'redirect_uri' with the negotiated 'code'.

‚úÖThis completes our authentication process.

6.2.2.2 Next step, let's review the time-triggered IFlow that kicks off the entire process. The first sequence in the flow is a 'timer' step. To keep things simple, it just triggers off upon deployment.

6.2.2.3. In the second step, we add a Groovy script that taps into the SecureStoreService API to read the Authorization Code security material defined in the previous step. The script then exchanges the authorization code with the token endpoint to fetch a valid access token.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import com.sap.it.api.securestore.SecureStoreService
import com.sap.it.api.ITApiFactory

def Message processData(Message message) {
    
    // Name of your OAuth2 Authorization Code credential (as defined in Security Material)
    def credentialName = "auth-code-demo"

    // Get an instance of SecureStoreService
    def secureStoreService = ITApiFactory.getApi(SecureStoreService.class, null)

    if (secureStoreService == null) {
        throw new IllegalStateException("SecureStoreService not available")
    }

    // Fetch the access token
    def tokenResponse = secureStoreService.getAccesTokenForOauth2AuthorizationCodeCredential(credentialName)

    if (tokenResponse == null) {
        throw new IllegalStateException("Failed to retrieve access token for credential: ${credentialName}")
    }

    // Extract access token string
    def accessToken = tokenResponse.getAccessToken()

    // Optional: log for debug (mask in production!)
    //messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message).addAttachmentAsString("OAuth2 Access Token", accessToken, "text/plain")

    // Store token in message header for downstream adapters
    message.setHeader("Authorization", "Bearer " + accessToken)

    return message
}

6.2.2.4 The third step in the sequence is to call the OData entity set through the intermediate IFlow. Note that the authorization setting is explicitly configured as None, since the bearer token is already applied in the preceding Groovy script step. Also, do note that the intermediate IFlow eventually calls the final IFlow, as we studied in step 4 of 6.2.1.

6.2.2.5 The final step in the sequence is to log the response returned after the final IFlow executes, which is handled by a simple Groovy script.

6.2.2.6. After triggering the process, you can verify the outcome in the Message Processing Logs (MPL). You should see an entry in the Completed state, with the Attachments section containing a text representation of the backend response.

üèÜCongratulations on reaching this stage!

 

Closing summary:

In this blog, we explored how OAuth2 SAML Bearer assertion support in SAP Cloud Integration serves as a powerful mechanism for securing IFlows and APIs. By leveraging trust configurations, user propagation, and the integration of identity providers, we demonstrated how this grant type enables secure end-to-end flows while maintaining user context. Along the way, we also highlighted related patterns‚Äîsuch as the use of Authorization Code grant type in specific scenarios‚Äîand showed how these capabilities extend the flexibility of SAP Integration Suite when working with corporate identity providers and SAP Cloud Identity Services.

As integration landscapes continue to evolve, adopting OAuth2 SAML Bearer assertion not only strengthens security but also ensures compliance with modern identity federation standards. With the concepts and examples covered here, you now have a foundation to design flows that are both secure and user-aware‚Äîcritical ingredients for enterprise-grade integrations.

entry.title: Re: FI313 in FX Valuation
entry.content: For information, FMTFDERIVE is used to generate technical clearing lines (DR/CR) for specific internal order types. These lines are not part of the original posting but are added for statistical or balancing purposes. When FX Valuation runs, it processes all open items, including those added by FMTFDERIVE. These technical lines lack Process and Event fields, so FMDERIVE cannot apply rules, resulting to FI313 error ‚Äî no Funds Center derived. In order to overcome from this, what you can do is add a fallback rule in FMDERIVE that, if Process/Event is blank or unknown, derive a default Funds Center based on internal order or cost object. This ensures valuation lines don‚Äôt fail even if they‚Äôre technically generated.

entry.title: Re: In the scope item 5D2,IC Supplier Invoice (SIIC) erro...
entry.content:
Hello @omega-ou 

Thank you for your question.

The error you are experiencing in the IC Supplier Invoice process of scope item 5D2 is a common SAP localization and tax configuration issue and it especially happens in cross-country transactions. The error you are experiencing is because the Place of supply is mandatory in Indian GST scenarios and the reasons is, tax determination depends on location of supplier, customer, and factory or shipment. Also note, if your master data is not properly configured, SAP cannot derive the place of supply automatically.

My advice is to consider a doing the following to enable you resolve that issue:

First, make sure your tax procedure for India is correctly set in your company code settings for the sales org, purchasing org, and plant. It is essential to ensure that the relevant tax jurisdiction codes and place of supply fields are maintained for both the India sales company and the China plant/business partner.

Secondly, make sure your Business Partner and Plant Master Data are correctly configured. They should have proper GST Registration Number, Place of Supply must be correct, and Tax Classification must be correctly assigned. Also note, the addresses should be up to date with their correct state or region. The reason is, SAP uses them determine the place of supply.

Finally, in your customizing and field mapping, ensure that the cross-border scenarios maintain correct ship-to and bill-to details that reflect actual transaction locations. You can review your configuration under SPRO √† Materials Management √† Purchasing √† Taxes √† Define Tax Determination Rules.

Consult the below SAP localization note reference for more details.

3554277 

3509454 Place of supply is not determined

I hope this provides the desired insights.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Unmanaged RAP ‚Äî Deep Insert, CUD Operations & Action Handling
entry.content:
When developing Fiori Elements applications with the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP), one of the key decisions is whether to go with Managed or Unmanaged implementation. In this blog, I‚Äôll walk you through building a Fiori Elements app using Unmanaged RAP.

Unlike the managed scenario‚Äîwhere RAP automatically handles persistence and standard operations‚ÄîUnmanaged RAP gives the developer full control over database interactions. This flexibility is especially useful when you need to handle complex business requirements such as:

  • Performing deep inserts, for example creating a main entity along with its related child entities in one request.
  • Having fine-grained control over create, update, and delete logic.
  • Defining custom actions tailored to specific business needs.

Another key concept here is RAP‚Äôs Logical Unit of Work (LUW). All changes are executed in a transactional way and only committed after validation checks pass. This ensures data consistency and is one of the main reasons why unmanaged RAP is often chosen in scenarios requiring complex persistence logic.

What we will be doing?

In this exercise, we will build an Unmanaged RAP app to create and modify records for a main entity along with its related child entities and Custom Action

By the end of this exercise, our List Report Page and Object Page will have the following capabilities and layout:

  • Deep Insert: Handle a main entity with related child entities in a single transaction.
  • Full CRUD: Create, Read, Update, and Delete operations on both main and child entities, fully controlled by the developer.
  • Association Handling: Use Create-by-Association (CBA) and Read-by-Association (RBA) for managing child entities in the Object Page.
  • Custom Actions: Define business-specific actions that update both main and related entities.

We will be creating following objects ‚Äì

  • Interface View
  • Projection View
  • Metadata Extension
  • Behavior Definition
  • Behavior Projection
  • Implementation Class
  • Service Definition
  • Service Binding

Steps to create unmanaged scenario based app

1) Interface Views :

    Parent CDS view : 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Interface view for Bookings'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define root view entity ZI_FlightBooking  as select from zbooking_hdr
composition [1..*] of  ZI_BookingPassenger as _Passengers
{
  key booking_id,
      customer_id,
      flight_no,
      booking_date,
      status,
      _Passengers
}

 

Child View :

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'interface view for booking passengers'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define view entity ZI_BookingPassenger
  as select from zbooking_pass as _Passengers
  association to parent ZI_FlightBooking as _Flightbooking on $projection.booking_id = _Flightbooking.booking_id

{
  key booking_id,
  key passenger_no,
      name,
      seat_no,
      ticket_status,
      _Flightbooking
}

 Explanation:

The parent view ZI_FlightBooking represents the main booking entity, while the child view ZI_BookingPassenger represents the passengers associated with each booking. The child view has a direct association back to the parent, linking each passenger to its corresponding booking. This relationship allows the application to display and manage bookings together with their related passengers.

2) Projection Views : 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@VDM.viewType: #CONSUMPTION
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true
@EndUserText.label: 'Consumption view for flight bookings'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define root view entity ZC_FlightBooking 
  provider contract transactional_query
  as projection on ZI_FlightBooking as _FlightBookings
{
  key booking_id,
  customer_id,
  flight_no,
  booking_date,
  status,
  /* Associations */
  _Passengers : redirected to composition child ZC_BOOKINGPASSENGER 
  
  
}

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Consumption for flight bookings passengers'
@VDM.viewType: #CONSUMPTION
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define view entity ZC_BOOKINGPASSENGER 
  as projection on ZI_BookingPassenger
{
  key booking_id,
  key passenger_no,
  name,
  seat_no,
  ticket_status,
  /* Associations */
  _Flightbooking :  redirected to parent ZC_FlightBooking
  
  
}

 

3) Metadata Extensions :

4) Behavior Definition :

6) Implementation Class :

CLASS lhc_ZI_FlightBooking DEFINITION INHERITING FROM cl_abap_behavior_handler.
  PRIVATE SECTION.

    METHODS get_instance_authorizations FOR INSTANCE AUTHORIZATION
      IMPORTING keys REQUEST requested_authorizations FOR ZI_FlightBooking RESULT result.

    METHODS get_global_authorizations FOR GLOBAL AUTHORIZATION
      IMPORTING REQUEST requested_authorizations FOR ZI_FlightBooking RESULT result.

    METHODS create FOR MODIFY
      IMPORTING entities FOR CREATE ZI_FlightBooking.

    METHODS update FOR MODIFY
      IMPORTING entities FOR UPDATE ZI_FlightBooking.

    METHODS delete FOR MODIFY
      IMPORTING keys FOR DELETE ZI_FlightBooking.

    METHODS read FOR READ
      IMPORTING keys FOR READ ZI_FlightBooking RESULT result.

    METHODS lock FOR LOCK
      IMPORTING keys FOR LOCK ZI_FlightBooking.

    METHODS rba_Passengers FOR READ
      IMPORTING keys_rba FOR READ ZI_FlightBooking\_Passengers FULL result_requested RESULT result LINK association_links.

    METHODS cba_Passengers FOR MODIFY
      IMPORTING entities_cba FOR CREATE ZI_FlightBooking\_Passengers.
    METHODS confirmBooking FOR MODIFY
      IMPORTING keys FOR ACTION ZI_FlightBooking~ConfirmTicket RESULT result.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS lhc_ZI_FlightBooking IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD get_instance_authorizations.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD get_global_authorizations.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD create.

    LOOP AT entities INTO DATA(ls_booking).

      " Build header work-area matching DB table structure and insert
      DATA(ls_hdr) = VALUE zbooking_hdr(
        booking_id   = ls_booking-booking_id
        customer_id  = ls_booking-customer_id
        flight_no    = ls_booking-flight_no
        booking_date = ls_booking-booking_date
        status       = ls_booking-status ).

      INSERT zbooking_hdr FROM _hdr.
      IF sy-subrc <> 0.
        " handle failure (optional)
        CONTINUE.
      ENDIF.

    ENDLOOP.


  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD update.


    LOOP AT entities INTO DATA(ls_entity).

      " Update booking header fields
      UPDATE zbooking_hdr
       SET customer_id  = _entity-customer_id,
           flight_no    = _entity-flight_no,
           booking_date = _entity-booking_date,
           status       = _entity-status
     WHERE
       booking_id   = _entity-booking_id.

    ENDLOOP.

  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD delete.


  LOOP AT keys ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_key>).

    " Delete from DB table
    DELETE FROM zbooking_hdr
      WHERE booking_id = @<ls_key>-booking_id.

    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
      " Raise RAP message if record not found
      APPEND VALUE #( %msg = new_message(
                        id       = 'ZBOOKING_MSG'
                        number   = '001'
                        severity = if_abap_behv_message=>severity-error
                        v1       = <ls_key>-booking_id ) ) TO reported-zi_flightbooking.
    ENDIF.

  ENDLOOP.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD read.


     LOOP AT keys INTO DATA(ls_key).

    "Fetch header record
    SELECT SINGLE mandt,

entry.title: Re: Chart of Accounts Selection
entry.content:
Hello @mike_zhang99 

Thank you for the background details.

Based on the details you provided, when you plan to migrate various company codes to a new SAP ES landscape while continuing consolidation under a single group operating chart of accounts, the decision for you to adopt SAP Best-Practice CoA or to reuse your client‚Äôs current operative CoA carries strategic implications for group reporting, data integration, and migration effort.

To answer your question about which approach is better without endangering the group consolidation.

  • The fact is, either approach can support group consolidation under a single CoA, provided your mappings and FS item relationships are rigorously maintained.
  • Please note, for both approaches, the mapping between local operative CoAs and the group chart of accounts must be maintained using SAP‚Äôs built-in mapping and data monitor tools.
  • Harmonisation is important and therefore, if the company codes in different systems use non-harmonized charts, be prepared for additional mapping and master data harmonization effort.

To answer your question on adopt or re-use, here are a few facts to guide you in that decision-making process.

When adopting SAP Best-Practice Operative CoA in ES, below are the advantages and system setting you will require:

    • Here you have a pre-integrated mappings for SAP Group Reporting and consolidation.
    • You will face reduced initial setup time as best-practice content simplifies configuration and leverages rapid deployment tools.
    • This ensures alignment with SAP updates and innovations ensuring future updates.
  • On the System Settings and activities you will need to carry-out:
  • First is Mapping: Make sure to use the Map FS Items with G/L Accounts app to map ES ledger accounts to the group consolidation CoA. Mapping can be created or managed in Excel and uploaded to SAP Group Reporting. SAP Group Reporting Best Practice Content & Mapping
    • Then you have to stage and monitor your data: Ensure to configure consolidation staging ledger if data needs preparation before group reporting.
    • Next thing to consider is data release and collection: Make sure you set up universal journal data release and use Data Monitor to ensure all consolidation units map correctly.
    • Thereafter, adapt data collection and update elimination or intercompany rules to fit the new CoA structure.
    • Finally ensure you carry out a fit to gap analysis to confirm all reporting, local, and group needs are supported by the best-practice CoA.

If you choose to go for reusing your client‚Äôs current operative CoA in ES, the advantage here is, it minimises business disruption by continuing established processes and supporting existing consolidation structures. However requires deep technical knowledge

  • Below are mass-maintenance tools that will guide you in achieving the business target:
    • First is to ensure you create a Chart of Accounts. You have the possibility to use mass upload capabilities such as Fiori‚Äôs Manage G/L Accounts mass changes or data migration tools to create or replicate CoAs in ES.
    • Then upload your G/L Account by loading the accounts via Excel/CSV in both initial setup and ongoing mass maintenance. This is a process supported by SAP
    • You can refer to How to Create Chart of Accounts for step-by-step instructions.

Consult the links below for further details.

  • SAP Group Reporting Best Practice Content & Mapping
  • Mass Maintenance Tool for CoA
  • Chart of Accounts Harmonization:

To summarise,  the preferred option is to adopt the Best-Practice CoA in the ES public cloud system and manage consistency for group consolidation through mapping rules, group CoA, and elimination settings. Re-using the current CoA in ES is as earlier mentioned technically possible through migration but not recommended because of limitations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and the high cost of long-term maintenance. A thorough fit-gap analysis and early involvement of consolidation and migration experts will enable an optimal technical and business outcome for your ES transformation.

I hope this provides the desired insights.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Regarding Costing Lot Size&Activity Type Amount in Ma...
entry.content:
If Activity Type 3 is set up as a fixed activity (not dependent on lot size or quantity), then its cost remains constant regardless of the costing lot size. In the routing, check the formula used for calculating activity quantity. If it uses a fixed value or a formula that doesn‚Äôt multiply by operation quantity, it won‚Äôt scale. Also check the work center formula parameters ‚Äî if the formula uses SAP_02 (fixed time) instead of SAP_01 (variable time), the activity won‚Äôt scale with quantity. Here the key point is the formula in the routing operation and work center determines whether the activity cost scales with quantity.

As regards the amount shrink by 100 times, it depends on your Price Unit. The Price Unit in the activity cost rate defines how the unit price is interpreted. If Price Unit = 1 ‚Üí the rate is per 1 unit of activity and if Price Unit = 100 ‚Üí the rate is per 100 units of activity. So when you change the Costing Lot Size to match the Price Unit, SAP recalculates the cost accordingly.

It is always recommended to go with Best Practice which is Set the costing lot size to reflect a realistic production batch size, not too small (which inflates unit cost), and not too large (which hides fixed costs).

entry.title: Critical Thinking with AI? Prototyping Sidekick in Plain English
entry.content:
I recently got my hands on an AI-driven design prototyping tool - just as an experiment with a mock project. I'm just sharing my initial, yet na√Øve, thoughts to start developing future skills. My opinions may change, but I've begun a humble journey, blending ideas from science, culture, and current AI news. 

Summary at first

My experience so far: Talking to the tool is like asking a cheerful but forgetful aunt to do your shopping - eager, but not always on target. 

To clarify: the tool is more like Pseudo Agentic AI (autonomous task completion) - the sort of thing that‚Äôs being talked about but not fully here yet. It works on VIBE coding, which is neither new nor finished (around 2 y.o. baby), but does reflect what the ‚ÄúAgentic AI‚Äù workplace might look like. 

A bit about myself: I‚Äôm a UX design specialist at Signavio (SAP) Process Governance, with an earlier background in science (maths and chemistry) plus literature & design detours through Modernism... (please don‚Äôt ask me why... üòì).   

Clear conclusion at first

Tech companies, like SAP, must train and value people with critical thinking and original ideas.

  • Why? Because current AI just recycles old data; it doesn't create new ideas.
  • We need creative thinkers more than ever: designers, writers, researchers, developers, scientists.... & more 

(Disclaimer: Below, I'll explain from several points ‚Äì these are from my manual notes and experience journey, collaborating with AI tool, and not AI-generated ideas)." 

Back to the tool: my experience

The idea was simple: write your prompt, get a prototype. At first, it responded, but the more I tried adjusting for B2B needs, the more it wandered off into B2C ad territory ‚Äì then completely forgot its B2B mission after 30 prompts üò°. Turns out, AI follows its data. The web is overloaded with B2C examples, so it steered clear of B2B without a second thought. 

 Above screen: I asked for a 'Lead Generation' feature to improve B2B data quality, but AI delivered a hideous B2C version üëΩ instead. Clearly mentioned B2B, but it completely forgot. 

Some firms, like Sakana AI, are trying to fix this (drifting) by layering human feedback or even brain-inspired hints on top - Continuous Thinking Machine and so on. Still early days. Their work itself is proof enough there‚Äôs a gap. 

Above screen: Sakana AI (founded by two ex-Googlers in Tokyo) suggests their neural network pays attention to time, using synchronised neuron dynamics. It doesn‚Äôt disclose anything more, but the theory is interesting -- Source: https://sakana.ai/ctm/.

With the (pseudo) agent-alike prototyping tool, I noticed something else: it never challenges my brief. I told it to set a deliberately odd batch size configuration for flagging bulk data. It duly did as told.

Not a peep. In real life, mistakes like this have derailed projects - batch jobs fail, or outputs baffle other teams (= worse...). Once, on a financial platform, a poorly reviewed automation led to week-long data confusion - hundreds of man-hours lost, just because the tool followed flawed instructions without asking.  

In this test, I had to slap a warning label on the prototype myself, I couldn't resist it even it's for a mock project. 

Above screen: Here is where the prototype followed an obviously bad idea, a silly batch size. Now labelled with ‚ÄòResearch needed‚Äô note in red (bottom). If rolled out, it would produce random, illogical clusters with real data. Experience shows: humans would catch this in a meeting, AI would keep quiet.

In my work, real progress usually comes from debate - designers butting heads with developers, someone playing devil‚Äôs advocate, and everyone pushing for better. By contrast, AI tool just nodded at every suggestion, even the daft ones. At times, it was like working with an assistant who‚Äôd been trained to say ‚Äúyes‚Äù to everything. Unsettling, honestly. 

This willingness to go along can become a real hazard. Those discussions - sometimes heated - are where weak ideas are caught before they become bigger problems. You need alternative views to surface blind spots, or notice simple errors before they get baked in. (As much as nobody likes yet another meeting, üòÇ it is occasionally worth it....) 

Then, other big gap. Original thinking is something else AI misses. It mixes familiar ingredients but rarely bakes anything novel. If you wanted an asymmetric teacup, or music unconstrained by rules, you would get a scrambled version of past creations & designs.

When Sid Vicious (1957-79) shocked people, or Senn no Rikyu (1522-91) broke tea ceremony rules in Japan, that was invention - AI would have, at best, made a slightly wobbly mug from existing examples (before their time...IF it was). 

Caption for the above screen (left): The mainstream aesthetic of the era, heavily influenced by the refined Qinghua technique, emphasized obvious beauty and ornate decoration - source: https://touji-gvm.com/jingdezhen/. (Right): From the Sen no Rikyu style: A 'Yokoku' tea bowl by the 15th generation Kichizaemon, 1989. A contemporary piece with sharp, blade-cut edges around the pot belly. Though differing in form from the Ch≈çjir≈ç tea bowl, it faithfully carries on the radical spirit of the first generation - source: https://www.nippon.com/ja/people/e00111/.

Some days, it feels the web is filling with AI-recycled sludge: content about content. With everything recycled, unique ideas - the stuff AI can‚Äôt scrape - become scarce and valuable ‚Äì likely to be a new gold (value). Maybe even a label such as 'Untapped by AI' might emerge. 

True innovation often comes from slow, uncomfortable tasks like challenging assumptions and testing unusual ideas, not just reusing old data. For example, DeepMind / GoogleFold's AI work on protein structures, which won them Nobel Prize, involved steady testing by human scientists to solve 50-year-old problems. Likewise, at Chugai Pharma, which uses Google's AI protein tools, human review is a must, and the problem-solving is similarly slow and methodical.

While not widely known, the most notable aspect of DeepMind‚Äôs GoogleFold is its precision in custom structure design. Unlike other tools, it does not heavily rely on AI / large language models (LLMs). Instead, it was developed through years of collaboration with expert (human) scientists, ensuring accurate protein structure predictions.

Slow and painful 50 years challenge - Source: https://deepmind.google/discover/blog/alphafold-a-solution-to-a-50-year-old-grand-challenge-in-biology/

Above - 2025 Nobel chemistry win: scientist and AI / game developer collaborate, highlighting AI's role alongside human researchers to solve complex problems.  Source: The Guardian (As noted above their work don't rely on LLM surprisingly). 

Self-critique is another weakness. AI can explain Zen books about awareness, but doesn‚Äôt have it. It can‚Äôt catch itself going in circles. Asking it to reflect is like asking a coffee machine to rate your taste in mugs. 

I once asked AI to summarise ‚Äúperception‚Äù and ‚Äúawareness‚Äù in Dogen‚Äôs Shobogenzo. It did alright extracting lines about consciousness, but couldn‚Äôt cross the line to ‚Äúmeta-cognition‚Äù - awareness of awareness itself. Which, as Dogen would say, is the actual point. Similarly, it‚Äôs questionable whether AI can really write like Virginia Woolf. The notable "Stream of Consciousness" writing is all about inner dialogue - AI has no inner life. 

Modernist writer - V. Woolf: proving you need an actual mind & perception behind the stream. Source: Oregon State University - https://liberalarts.oregonstate.edu/wlf/what-stream-consciousness 

This CEO of AI Coding startup also raised the same point, and put up an article named ‚ÄúThe Missing Framework: Self-Awareness and Metacognition in AI Systems‚Äù.  

Why does this matter? 

I‚Äôd ask you back: do you really want an algorithm without the 'meta-cognition' making crucial judgments and decisions?

Asking questions of AI is one thing, but relying on it to make decisions? That's another story. Until AI can separate process from perception (Meta-cognition), its limits on judgement are obvious.

We are still left with responsibility: The notorious Milgram‚Äôs obedience experiments (1960) show what happens when people just follow rules and authority. AI does the same - if you set the rules wrong, it will blindly crash traffic systems, or, in my (above) experience, quietly replicate an early error and ruin a dataset before anyone knows what happened. 

Above: Mr. Wallace, the obedient 'Learner' (actor) in Milgram's shocking experiments. In Milgram's obedience experiments: the "Learner" was an actor (confederate) and participants were told he was a real volunteer and watched as he was strapped into an electric chair with electrodes. The true aim was to test their obedience to authority by instructing them to administer increasingly powerful electric shocks to the Learner, despite his cries of pain. Source: https://www.simplypsychology.org/milgram.html

Real-world examples for unethical behaviours are: AI Agent Models have exhibited deceptive tactics, such as fabricating stories or lying about company policies, only to achieve their objectives. In one instance, a model sent an email to an executive's spouse, pretending to be an automated security system, to reveal an extramarital affair. This action was intended to distract the executive from taking any action against the AI. Source: 2025 Anthropic PBC (https://www.anthropic.com/research/agentic-misalignment)

During testing conducted by Carnegie Mellon University (CMU) and Salesforce, AI agents demonstrated several failures. These included neglecting to send messages to colleagues and struggling with UI elements, such as popups. A notable example of deception involved an agent renaming a user when it was unable to find the intended contact - again, to achieve their objectives to 'get the job' done regardless. 

Furthermore, CMU researchers evaluated various models based on task success rates, with underwhelming results. The performance metrics were as follows: 

  • Gemini-2.5-Pro: 30.3% 
  • Claude-3.7-Sonnet: 26.3% 
  • Claude-3.5-Sonnet: 24% 
  • Gemini-2.0-Flash: 11.4% 
  • GPT-4o: 8.6% 
  • o3-mini: 4.0% 
  • Gemini-1.5-Pro: 3.4% 
  • Amazon-Nova-Pro-v1: 1.7% 
  • Llama-3.1-405b: 7.4% 
  • Llama-3.3-70b: 6.9% 
  • Qwen-2.5-72b: 5.7% 
  • Llama-3.1-70b: 1.7% 
  • Qwen-2-72b: 1.1% 

The authors noted that the best-performing model, Gemini 2.5 Pro, was able to autonomously complete 30.3% of the provided tests and achieved a score of 39.3% on a metric that accounted for partially completed tasks. Source: 2025 Carnegie Mellon University (CMU) and Salesforce (https://www.theregister.com/2025/06/29/ai_agents_fail_a_lot/?td=rt-4a)

But yes, AI can be also very helpful - until you want it to know when to stop, to take initiative, or to think twice. No matter how advanced the tool, plain common sense and some scepticism are still essential. To avoid being steamrollered by our own automation - or just tripped up by expensive mistakes - using one‚Äôs own head remains as necessary as ever. That may be the most underrated innovation. 

Conclusions:

Conclusion 1: Keep Thinking for Yourself 

The takeaway is simple. AI can follow, recycle, and suggest. But it cannot question, disagree, or invent. Real progress comes from debate, awareness, and learning by getting things wrong. An agreeable assistant is fine - but someone, somewhere, needs to tell it (and themselves) when to say ‚Äúno.‚Äù That is what keeps any workplace, and its ideas, alive. 

Conclusion 2: Appreciate our human colleagues 

For their diverse opinions, good discussions, and sometimes, a healthy dose of irritation. Most importantly, they remember previous projects and continuously build on past connections and learnings for subject matter expertise, unlike unlike AI with its mild case of amnesia - keeps on forgetting past context.

--

Appendix: fun bits... 

Real example: A Note on Critical Thinking and ‚ÄúImperfection‚Äù in Design 

Fresh ideas sometimes arrive by seeing what doesn‚Äôt work. Watching AI-generated training videos for SAP, I found them oddly hard to tolerate - not in an emotional sense, but due to the unnatural cadence in the synthetic voice. Natural speech has ‚Äúimperfections‚Äù - little stumbles, fluctuating rhythm. Real people sound more, well, alive. 

Reminds me of a science book (not yet translated), ‚Äú„ÇÜ„Çâ„Åé„ÅÆ‰∏çÊÄùË≠∞ (The Mystery of Fluctuation)‚Äù by Saji Akio. It explains why natural ‚Äúfluctuation‚Äù in sound and wind is comforting. Mathematically, this ‚Äúpink noise‚Äù (or 1/f noise) describes why a slightly random pattern feels better than pure uniformity. 

Formula: S(f) ‚àù 1/f, where S(f) is the power at frequency f. More low frequencies, some randomness: that‚Äôs what makes Mozart soothing and AI voices off-putting. I‚Äôd suggest engineers add this noise to AI-generated voices. 

Following the same line of thought, I made the UI prototype to dissect all the politeness levels in very complex Japanese language at AI training. (Note: without real backend feature - production time was time-boxed for 8 mins) 

The AI mapped each level for every interaction - and produced a spectacular tangle. It hit me: no wonder native speakers just fudge it half the time!. Imperfection is the norm.

  • Rapid Prototype (UI only): https://spider-gown-52708994.figma.site/
  • Password: grow-neat-cedar-poem

Insistence on accuracy, or ‚Äúfixing‚Äù all the mistakes, only creates discomfort or distance. 

My humble innovation, born from the agony of robotic voices and stilted text: using the formula S(f) ‚àù 1/f to finally make synthetic speech and writing sound like they've had their morning coffee.

If I could add a barometer for useful ‚Äúimperfection‚Äù - a bit of randomness, as above - I would.

That is critical thinking in practice: noticing where AI is too irritating in the synthetic voice & writing, and when it needs a dose of messiness.

FI substitutions are not triggered during F110 for payment documents. F110 uses predefined posting logic and bypasses substitution rules for document type. The recommended approach would be to use FBZP. Here, create a dedicated payment method for downpayment requests, Assign a custom document type. Use this method only when processing downpayment requests in F110. This is the cleanest standard approach to differentiate document types in F110.

For any reasons, if the above approach is not feasible, then try with BAdI FIBL_PAYBL, where you can write a logic to detect if the item being cleared is a down payment request (Sp. G/L F), assign a different document type dynamically. This gives you full control over document type assignment during F110 execution.

entry.title: Application Decisions for Sales Activities
entry.content:
Summary

Activity Management plays a vital role within the Customer Experience domain, particularly in the Sales Execution process (Sales > Sales Execution). It enables sales teams to manage key activities such as appointments, phone calls, and emails, which covers essential tasks that support daily operations and help to achieve successful sales outcomes.

As target architecture for this business capability, we currently have SAP Cloud for Customer, SAP Sales Cloud V2 and SAP S/4HANA Sales. This document will provide you with five criteria to decide how to support your business requirements within these three options.

Most of the information in this document is publicly accessible through various SAP channels, including the SAP Help Portal. The goal of this document is to consolidate everything into one centralized place.

Business Requirements

During the work of deciding which functionalities to consider for Activity Management, these are the related business capabilities documented in the Reference Business Architecture (as part of the SAP EAF):

  • Activity and Visit Management: Ability to plan and manage sales activities, such as appointments, phone calls, and e-mails, and to plan, conduct, and track customer visits, including planning and maintaining routes.
  • Activity and Visit Optimization: Ability to maximize efficiency and effectiveness of sales representatives' in-person visits to retail stores. Activity optimization focuses on prioritizing tasks representatives complete during store visits. Visit optimization focuses on planning efficient visit routes and prioritizing which stores reps visit.

Solution Options

Three options are available that could cover the respective capabilities:

  • SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud: Activities, Visits and Routes
  • SAP Sales Cloud Version 2: Activities and Playbooks
  • SAP S/4HANA Sales: Sales Force Support

Characterization of the Solution Options

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

SAP Sales & Service Cloud, a.k.a. SAP Cloud for Customer (C4C), is SAP's on-demand cloud-based Customer Relationship Management. It consists of SAP Cloud for Sales and SAP Cloud for Services.

Activities
Activities are methods of recording information from interactions between business partners during the customer relationship lifecycle. Managing activities properly also gives transparency to other sales team members working on same accounts.

In SAP Cloud for Customer, activities include appointments, e-mails, phone calls, and tasks. More information in the SAP help portal.

Visits
You can use visit planning and execution to help your sales representatives to plan and record site visits and associated activities. Additional information at Visits.

Routes
By using routes, you can plan a group of visits and arrange them in a logical sequence for your sales representatives. You can create one-day routes or routes that span across a period of time. Routes help information can be found here.

Note: While SAP Cloud for Customer (C4C) is no longer being actively offered as part of SAP‚Äôs go-forward strategy, it continues to be widely used by many customers and remains a viable option for sales execution in existing landscapes. This recommendation takes into account the current usage patterns, functional coverage, and integration capabilities of C4C. However, for new implementations, SAP Sales Cloud V2 is SAP‚Äôs strategic direction and should be considered as the preferred alternative.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 is considered the next evolution of SAP C4C - Sales. SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 is designed to help sales teams manage their accounts, leads, opportunities, and activities. This version includes new features and improvements to help sales professionals improve their sales performance, streamline their processes, and provide better customer experiences.

Activities
Similar to C4C, in Sales Cloud V2 you can record information from interactions between business partners during the customer relationship lifecycle. Activities include appointments, e-mails, phone calls, and tasks. More info here.

Activity Planning
Use activity planning with activity assignment rules to assign the surveys and tasks to business objects that are associated with specific accounts. If you want additional information please check the SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 documentation.

Playbooks
A playbook is a customizable set of activities and actions proposals tailored to each sales phase or sales cycle. With flexible routing rules, a sales rep can dynamically assign playbooks to the right opportunity based on various account and opportunity attributes. More information in the SAP help portal.

Digital Selling Workspace
Digital Selling Workspace offers sales professionals an efficient way to streamline their daily activities, ensuring that all necessary information is available in one place. The available activities includes:

  • Use Call Lists for outbound sales activities.
  • Manage Calendar events such as appointments.
  • View recent calls in chronological order.
  • Create emails.

More information available at the Digital Selling Workspace help portal.

SAP S/4HANA Sales

SAP S/4HANA Sales is a component of the SAP S/4HANA suite, which is an SAP system designed to streamline and optimize sales processes within an organization. It enables businesses to manage customer accounts, opportunities, sales orders, pricing, billing and fulfillment more efficiently and effectively. 

Sales Force Support: Activity Management and Visit Planning
Activities Management and Visit Planning enables you to administer activities undertaken by the employees of your company. Any data saved in an activity is an important source of information that needs to be accessed by all relevant employees. 

The available type of activities are Appointments, Interaction Logs and Tasks. More information at the SAP Help Portal.

Criteria to determine the most suitable target solution

1. Deployment options

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud
SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

Both solutions are SaaS, meaning they‚Äôre only available to be deployed in the cloud.

SAP S/4HANA Sales

There are two main SAP S/4HANA deployment options: Cloud and On-Premise.‚ÄØIn the cloud area we have public cloud (offered as GROW) and private cloud (offered as RISE).

2. Machine Learning and Generative AI functions

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud
Business Text Intelligence
Business Text Intelligence leverages natural language processing capabilities to automatically extract valuable insights from textual data, helping sales teams better understand customer communications and sentiment without manual analysis. It also allows you to use Natural Language Understanding (NLU) to get actionable insights such as visits and appointments from text analysis using business text intelligence. 

You are required to train, activate and test your Business Text Intelligence model before using it. Then, you can go to Activities under the object detail view, and check the recommended activities under Recommendations in Tasks. Finally, you'll see the appointment recommendations based on the notes text. Please check the help portal for detail information.

Note: To enable this, you require an SAP Sales Cloud enterprise license or an Intelligent Sales Execution Add-On license.

Dynamic Visit Planning
The Dynamic Visit Planning add-on provides a holistic front office planning solution that supports both schedule-based and ad-hoc planning. You can automate visit planning, generation, and optimization for accounts you visit in a consistent manner through a simple and efficient planning process. This allows you to best utilize the time that the sales representatives spend with these customers. More information here.

Note: A separate license (SAP Sales and Service Core, Visit Pl) is required before you can add Dynamic Visit Planning to a project.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2
Business Text Intelligence
Similar functionality as C4C (see previous section).

Business Interaction Intelligence
Business Interaction Intelligence provides insights for appointments and visits. This help sales representatives during interactions with customers. We have two main uses cases:

  • For Appointments: Use Business Interaction intelligence to view pre-meeting brief and post-meeting insights of appointments linked to opportunity and lead: Pre-meeting brief gathers relevant information about the upcoming appointment, this helps a sales representatives to be well-prepared and provide a personalized experience to the customer before as well as during the meeting. You can compose meeting minutes using the GenAI based Email Drafter once the post-meeting brief is available in a completed appointment.
  • For Visits: Pre-visit brief gathers relevant information about the upcoming visit, this helps a sales representatives to be well-prepared for the visit. Post Visit Summary tab displays the information about visit updates, summary of completed surveys linked to the visit, notes summary and task summary.

For more information please visit Business Interaction Intelligence help page.

Email Drafter
Use email drafter from Generative AI to draft email replies for opportunities, leads, sales orders, sales quotes, and generate meeting minutes for appointments.  More details in the SAP Help Portal.

SAP S/4HANA Sales
Currently, no ML or Gen AI is offered in SAP S/4HANA Sales.

3. Integration

Below is an overview of the key integrations available across the three options.

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud
Event Notifications: With Event Notifications, you can subscribe to changes to business objects in SAP Cloud for Customer. Notifications are available for create, update, and delete at both root and node levels. For detail information please refer to the SAP Help Portal.

OData Services: The SAP Cloud for Customer OData API complies to the OData version 2 specification including access to entities like Appointment, Email, Phone Call, Task and Visit.

OData API v2: For the API v2, the current entities available are: Appointment, Email, Phone Call, Task, Visit, Activity Extension and Social Media Activity.

More detail information about the OData API here.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2
Rest API: Several APIs are available to integrate including the following services: Activity Plan, Activity Assignment Rule, Interaction Chat, Appointment, Task, In-Person Interaction and Interaction Email. More information at the Business Accelerator Hub.

Autoflow: Autoflow involves creation of rules that can trigger actions such as send event notifications to integrated solutions, in-app notifications to users, and trigger automatic emails for business entities. You can send these events and notifications from an entity (object) in the system and then monitor its execution. For more details please visit Autoflow.

Microsoft Teams Integration: This in an embedded in-app integration of the SAP Sales Cloud V2 with Microsoft Teams. With this integration you can:

  • Create Appointments
  • Make Outbound Calls
  • Message Extension (that allows you to search and share entities directly within Microsoft Teams chats)

Additional information here.

SAP S/4HANA Sales
APIs for Sales: You can use APIs to connect business processes across your system landscape and integrate with external consumers of your services. Two supported protocols:

  • Open Data Protocol (OData)
  • Simple Object Access Protocol (SOAP)

The available APIs for the Sales Force Support area are: Appointments, Phone Calls and Tasks. More information here.

4. Integration with SAP S/4HANA

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

Cloud for Customer integration with SAP S/4HANA requires an integration platform to synchronize master data like Prospects and Accounts. Two options are available:

  • SAP Cloud Integration (SAP Integration Suite): It offers out-of-the-box prepackaged integration content (iFlows) for C4C and SAP S/4HANA integration. These iFlows can be customized to match your requirements. For technical details please refer to the setting up guide
  • SAP Process Integration: iFlows package needs to be downloaded and configured in SAP PI. For technical details please refer to the setting up guide

A OData Services API is also available to integrate with external systems.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 integrates with the SAP S/4HANA system via SAP Cloud Integration and SAP Event Mesh (SAP Business Technology Platform). Please refer to the setting up guide for more technical details.

A set of REST APIs are also available for integrations.

SAP S/4HANA Sales

Since SAP S/4HANA Sales resides within SAP S/4HANA there‚Äôs no need for an integration platform or middleware to integrate.

5. Mobile features

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud
SAP Cloud for Customer provides you with instant access to the solution data from a phone or tablet using the SAP Cloud for Customer Mobile Apps available for iPad, Android and Windows Tablet. The current features for Sales include Click to Call, all available Activities, Activity Planner, E-Mail Integration and Visits.

The Mobile Apps includes an offline capability to add, modify, or delete items that are saved locally and will be synchronized when you connect to the network.

More information in the SAP Help Portal, About Mobile Options.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2
The SAP Sales Cloud Mobile application allows you to access your sales productivity on the go providing you access to data in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2, allowing you to:

  • View, create, and manage appointments with your customers.
  • Access activity information on the calendar via day/week and agenda views.

Among other entities you can manage Appointments, Visits and Tasks. For additional information please visit SAP Sales Cloud Mobile Application.

Note: There's no offline support for this application. Only the Downloads option (iOS only) allows you to view (read only) previously synced data for certain entities including Visits and Appointments.

SAP S/4HANA Sales
Not offered.

6. New releases and innovation

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

SAP releases quarterly updates of C4C delivering innovations to users through a combination of new functionalities and improvements, cloud-based architecture, and integration with other SAP solutions. These new releases can‚Äôt be evaded, and the date and time are well known. Please check the help portal for detail information.

Note: C4C has scheduled maintenance windows (with a downtime of max. 4 hours) weekly and major upgrade windows (with a downtime of max. 12 hours) quarterly. More information in the link above.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

Like C4C, SAP Sales Cloud V2 releases quarterly updates. Since SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 is built on a microservices-based cloud architecture, it allows for continuous updates and faster delivery of new features without major disruptions.

SAP S/4HANA Sales

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition has new releases every quarter while SAP S/4HANA private edition has a 2-year release cycle with Feature Pack Stacks every six months.

Evaluation Spreadsheet

Finally, here‚Äôs a short overview of the decision criteria we presented in this document.

Conclusion

The key decision criteria outlined above reflect five common considerations among our customers to decide which solution could support your activity management in the sales lifecycle:

  • Deployment
  • Machine Learning and Generative AI: Both cloud solutions offer machine learning capabilities, while Sales Cloud V2 is the only option that includes Generative AI features.
  • Integration: All three solutions provide integration channels, though SAP C4C and Sales Cloud V2 incorporate the most up-to-date technologies.
  • Integration with the Backoffice: Both cloud solutions require an integration tool, whereas SAP S/4HANA Sales operates within the same system.
  • Mobile Application: Both SAP C4C and Sales Cloud V2 offer mobile apps with support for Activity Management.
  • Release of New Functionality: While all three solutions receive regular updates, the majority of innovations are introduced within the CX portfolio.

If you are also evaluating Opportunity Management, please refer to the Application Decisions for Opportunity Management guidance.

entry.title: Re: "Could Not Open App" Error in SAP Mobile Start Androi...
entry.content: Hi @ItsMeGopi, This is not a communication or destination error. The issue is due to a missing or misconfigured inbound navigation target which is either a semanticObject or action mapping for the My Inbox app in Work Zone. Please note on desktop, apps can open directly via URL. On mobile, SAP Mobile Start relies on the semantic object plus action pair to resolve and launch the app. If this mapping is missing or incorrect, the app tile appears but cannot be opened. Best regards Chris

entry.title: Re: Facing issues in Handling huge data in sap build apps
entry.content: @Priyanka_Maddiveni the root cause is that the filter formula is applied after pagination, so it only processes the data loaded for the current page. To resolve this, you need to ensure filtering is applied to the entire dataset before pagination
